title: VC Daily: SoftBank Finalizing $4 Billion Loan From Apollo-Led Group; Question of the Week; We asked if Katie Haun's departure from Andreessen Horowitz to start her own crypto-focused fund was a sign of things to come in crypto venture investing
text:
Acrew Capital founding partner Lauren Kolodny said: "Whereas Andreessen has made big bets in Web3, we'll more commonly see GPs leave firms that don't already have good crypto infrastructure in place and where partnerships aren't nimble enough to adapt to what's required to invest successfully in this space."

Progress Ventures general partner Chris Legg said Ms. Haun's expertise in crypto at a marquee firm allowed her to win backing to start her own fund. "Most GPs are not this uniquely positioned (i.e., right place with right background coming from the right fund), so this is not an opportunity afforded to many."

This week's question: Will inflation crimp venture investment in 2022?

Please email responses to marc.vartabedian@wsj.com.

Top News

Loan deal. SoftBank Group Corp. is finalizing a $4 billion loan from Apollo Global Management Inc. backed by SoftBank's stable of technology-startup stakes, as the Japanese conglomerate seeks to weather turbulence in its portfolio, The Wall Street Journal reports.

The loan would be secured by SoftBank's second Vision Fund, people familiar with the matter said. That roughly $40 billion pot includes stakes in 150 companies such as Indian e-commerce giant Flipkart; digital-banking startup Revolut; and Cameo, a site where celebrities sell personalized messages. SoftBank can use the money for a range of purposes, one of the people said.

The deal between the investing giants shows SoftBank's ravenous need for cash and highlights Apollo's push into lending, a territory traditionally dominated by banks.

Novartis to Buy Gene-Therapy Company Targeting Eye Condition

Novartis AG has agreed to pay up to $1.5 billion to acquire British biotech Gyroscope Therapeutics, in a deal that will expand its pipeline of gene therapies targeting eye diseases, the Journal reports. The Swiss healthcare giant said Wednesday it would make an upfront payment of $800 million, and potential additional payments of up to $700 million, provided Gyroscope hits particular development milestones. The acquisition will hand Novartis an experimental gene therapy for geographic atrophy, a form of age-related macular degeneration that can lead to permanent vision loss. The treatment, known as GT005, is designed to increase the production of a protein, called CFI, that is thought to reduce damaging inflammation. That treatment is in midstage clinical trials. Gyroscope, which was founded five years ago by London-based life sciences investor Syncona Ltd., also has some earlier-stage projects aimed at other eye diseases.

Tech Show Faces Dilemma as Covid Cases Rise and Companies Stay Home

Organizers of CES 2022 are pressing ahead with plans to host tens of thousands of people in Las Vegas next month, setting up the technology conference as a test for mass business gatherings at a time when surging Covid-19 cases are prompting other companies and groups to change plans, the Journal reports. Several participants including Amazon.com Inc., Facebook parent Meta Platforms Inc. and Twitter Inc., and at least one keynote speaker, T-Mobile's chief executive, have withdrawn from the event. The Consumer Technology Association is kicking off the biggest U.S. tech conference the first week of January with a scaled-back crowd and vaccine and mask requirements. While there's a digital component, the organization expects 50,000 to 75,000 attendees at the Las Vegas Convention Center and other venues.

Thoma Bravo's A.J. Rohde Sees More Take-Private Deals in 2022

Technology-focused private-equity firms are witnessing a frenzied market for deals as businesses across all sectors of the economy have embraced technology to improve their operations. A.J. Rohde, a senior partner focused on the upper midmarket strategy for one of the largest of these firms, Thoma Bravo, spoke to WSJ Pro's Preeti Singh about the trends in technology investing and why he expects an uptick in acquisitions of publicly traded technology companies next year. Read more.

Industry News

IPO Tracking

Public transit software provider Via Transportation Inc. said it has confidentially filed paperwork with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, according to Dow Jones Newswires. The New York-based company didn't disclose the number of shares or the price range for the proposed offering. Via recently raised a $130 million Series G round at a $3.3 billion valuation from Janus Henderson, funds and accounts managed by BlackRock, ION Crossover Partners, Koch Disruptive Technologies and Exor.

Funds

Calibrate Ventures raised $97 million for its second fund to invest in early-stage artificial intelligence and automation startups. Founded in 2017, the Pasadena, Calif.-based firm has invested in startups including Built Robotics, FarmWise, HealthTensor, Parallel Domain and Trellis. Calibrate closed its inaugural fund with $80 million in 2018.

People

San Francisco-based Industry Ventures recently promoted Pat Hanson to chief compliance officer, named Jon Wong as a vice president on the tech buyout team and appointed Valerie Lau to the post of vice president of legal. Prior to joining Industry Ventures in July, Mr. Hanson was the vice president of finance and chief compliance officer for Dyson Capital Advisors. Mr. Wong was previously a vice president in BlackRock's Private Equity Partners group. Ms. Lau was an attorney at Latham & Watkins.

Sauce Labs Inc. appointed Abel Mathew as chief technology officer, replacing John Kelly, who was named chief strategy officer. Mr. Mathew joined Sauce Labs in July with the acquisition of Backtrace, where he was co-founder and chief executive. He previously held positions at AppNexus, IBM and AMD. San Francisco-based Sauce Labs is backed by investors including Adams Street Partners, Centerview Capital Technology, IVP, Riverwood Capital, Salesforce Ventures and Toba Capital.

Exits

Detection and response services provider GoSecure Inc. acquired Covail, a provider of intelligent security and risk optimization. Terms weren't disclosed. GoSecure is backed by investors including Yaletown Partners and Razor's Edge Ventures.

Kraken acquired fellow digital asset platform Staked for an undisclosed amount. Founded in 2011, Kraken is backed by investors including Tribe Capital, SkyBridge, Hummingbird Ventures, Blockchain Capital and Digital Currency Group. Staked is listed in the portfolios of Dreamers VC, Pantera Capital and Global Brain.

Robotic process automation startup Automation Anywhere agreed to purchase business analytics automation startup FortressIQ for an undisclosed sum. San Jose, Calif.-based Automation Anywhere is backed by Salesforce Ventures, New Enterprise Associates, General Atlantic and others. FortressIQ, of San Francisco, counts M12, Tiger Global Management, Boldstart Ventures, Comcast Ventures, Eniac Ventures and Lightspeed Venture Partners as investors.

New Money

OfBusiness, an Indian business-to-business commerce and financial services platform, raised a $325 million Series G round led by Alpha Wave Global, Tiger Global Management and Softbank Vision Fund 2, giving the company a valuation of around $5 billion.

Veho, a New York-based personalized next-day package delivery service, landed $125 million in Series A funding led by General Catalyst at a $1 billion valuation. Additional investors in the round included Construct Capital, Bling Capital, Industry Ventures, Fontinalis Partners and Origin Ventures.

Zepto, an Indian grocery delivery startup, secured $100 million in Series C funding, increasing the company's valuation to $570 million. Y Combinator Continuity led the round, which included additional support from Glade Brook Capital Partners, Nexus Venture Partners, Breyer Capital, Lachy Groom, Global Founders Capital, Contrary Capital and others.

PlainID, a provider of cybersecurity, authorization and identity access management technology, picked up $75 million in Series C financing. Insight Partners led the investment, which included contributions from Viola Ventures and others. The company also appointed Gil Levonai to chief marketing officer and Thomas Ammirati to chief revenue officer.

Yumi, a Los Angeles-based baby food startup, nabbed $67 million in Series B financing from investors including JAZZ Venture Partners and AF Ventures.

Multichain, a cross-chain router protocol, snagged a $60 million investment at a $1.2 billion valuation. Lead investor Binance Labs was joined by Sequoia Capital China, IDG Capital, Three Arrows Capital, DeFiance Capital, Circle Ventures, Hypersphere Ventures, Primitive Ventures, Magic Ventures and others in the round.

CHAI, a South Korea-based digital payments startup focused on Asia, raised a $45 million Series B+ round. Led by SoftBank Ventures Asia and Nyca Partners, the investment included support from KT Investment, Conductive Ventures, Nordstar Capital, Samsung NEXT and B Capital.

Cove.tool, an Atlanta-based provider of building design and construction software, closed a $30 million Series B investment. Coatue Management led the round, which saw participation from FootPrint Coalition, Mucker Capital, Urban Us and Knoll Ventures.

Carats & Cake, a New York-based provider of marketing and point-of-sale financing technology for venues and property groups, nabbed a $19.3 million investment. Acrew Capital and Founders Fund led the round, which included contributions from 1Sharpe Ventures, Correlation Ventures, GMO VenturePartners, Socially Financed and others.

Monoxer Inc., a Tokyo-based provider of a learning platform for memory retention, fetched 1.8 billion Japanese yen (about $16 million) in Series B funding from Global Brain, Z Venture Capital, Salesforce Ventures, World Innovation Lab and UB Ventures.
